title: Ticket #7109: Provide reasonable overloads for Undefined / Error in python
description:
One constant irritation in the python bindings is that the Value.Undefined evaluates to true. This is because boost python, when creating the Value class, utilizes the default integer overloads. Since, in ClassAds, Undefined is represented by the integer 1, Undefined becomes coerced to 1 which becomes coerced to True. Thus, both Undefined and Error are true!

Thus, because a + 1 evaluates to undefined, the following two statements have different behaviors: 

if classad.ExprTree("a + 1"):
   print "ta-da!"
if classad.ExprTree("a + 1").eval():
   print "ta-da!"

The second will print ta-da while the first does not. Surprise!

When discussing other surprising behaviors in #7107, I realized that we can, of course, overload the boost-provided operators for the classad.Value class. It's a bit awkward and not a first-class operation -- but not crazy either.
